N1.title: Color Lab (Present)

intro.speaker: NARRATOR
intro.text: The Color Lab wakes like a theatre: ceiling strips hum alive, glass panels flare, and the air itself seems to hold its breath.

intro.speaker: NARRATOR
intro.text: Six shapes drift into formation—three rectangles above, three triangles below—like a lock waiting for the right count.

intro.speaker: JESSICA
intro.text: Steady, {player}. This first node is a ritual of counting, not guessing.

intro.speaker: ARIA
intro.text: Then every color change is a clue, not decoration.

intro.speaker: JESSICA
intro.text: Watch how the upper row behaves across cycles; it follows a tight warm triad.

intro.speaker: JESSICA
intro.text: Now watch the lower row: the cold tones obey a stricter rhythm than the row above.

intro.speaker: JESSICA
intro.text: Trust the clock: the minutes tell you the size of one color pool. Then compute the total combinations.

hints.text: Start from time 04:10. Minutes (10) define the size of the cold-color pool.
For the 3 lower shapes, order matters and colors do not repeat in one frame: 10 x 9 x 8.
For the 3 upper shapes, only three warm tones are used and repetition is possible: 3 x 3 x 3.
Stuck too long? You can use solvelose colors, but answer reveal unlocks only after 5 minutes.

N1.era_story: The UNIX epoch dawns soon; terminals are raw, loud, and full of possibility.

N2.title: Chess Switchyard (1930)

intro.speaker: NARRATOR
intro.text: Switchboards clack like thunder while brass relays blink in strict rhythm.

intro.speaker: JESSICA
intro.text: {player}, this node rewards precision. A knight can strike two futures in one leap.

intro.speaker: JACK
intro.text: So one move should threaten both king and power.

intro.speaker: JESSICA
intro.text: Exactly. Find the fork square where panic and material loss happen together.

hints.text: The move is a knight fork on king + queen pressure. Visualize Ne7 first.
Use standard move form: piece + square. Example format: Ne7.
If your move attacks only one target, it is not the fork you want.

N2.era_story: Electromechanical logic is young—switches, relays, and chess-like planning shape computation.

N3.title: Code Observatory (2030)

intro.speaker: NARRATOR
intro.text: Glass walls bloom with code, branches, and overwrites like a storm of logic.

intro.speaker: JESSICA
intro.text: {player}, this is your routing exam: three short questions, no lucky guessing.

intro.speaker: JACK
intro.text: So I trace every assignment to the final destination.

intro.speaker: JESSICA
intro.text: Yes. First wrong try on each question costs points—slow thinking beats fast typing.

intro.speaker: NARRATOR
intro.text: The wrong branch is never random; it is usually one assumption made too quickly.

hints.text: There are three questions now: A, B, C. Solve each with: solve code <ID> <N#>.
Use showcode A/B/C and track final assignment, not the first value.
First wrong attempt on each question costs score once, so verify before submitting.

N3.era_story: AI copilots and distributed systems reshape software decisions at planetary scale.

N4.title: Regex Drift (Timeless)

intro.speaker: NARRATOR
intro.text: The room becomes a living console: strings mutate while regex gates pulse in sequence.

intro.speaker: JESSICA
intro.text: {player}, watch before you answer. Variations reveal the rule better than any lecture.

intro.speaker: JACK
intro.text: Four samples, five regex choices, then commit.

intro.speaker: JESSICA
intro.text: Right. Four rounds total. You gain and lose score each round, so stay sharp.

intro.speaker: NARRATOR
intro.text: Each regex choice feels like choosing a language to describe chaos.

hints.text: Read all 4 changing sample strings. Your regex must match every shown variation.
You choose among 5 regex options each round. Correct = +2, wrong = -2.
Complete 4 rounds, then the node unlocks regardless of total score.

games.answer: 4 rounds of regex picks; scoring is dynamic

N5.title: Binary Clock Grid (3000)

intro.speaker: NARRATOR
intro.text: A clock wall flickers in binary columns while a tic-tac-toe table rises from the floor.

intro.speaker: JESSICA
intro.text: {player}, time logic beats ego here: not every round should be a win.

intro.speaker: JACK
intro.text: So outcomes are bits? Win is 1, lose is 0?

intro.speaker: JESSICA
intro.text: Exactly. Build a 4-bit clock code from four rounds. The target rhythm is 1010.

hints.text: Map outcomes to bits: W=1, L=0. You need a 4-bit sequence.
Target scheme is WIN, LOSE, WIN, LOSE — binary 1010.
A draw breaks the pattern. Reset and replay the 4-round trial.

N5.era_story: Strategy engines train with game theory to coordinate humans and autonomous systems.

N6.title: Nim Arena (1970)

intro.speaker: NARRATOR
intro.text: Three Nim terminals boot in a row, each demanding a clean strategic finish.

intro.speaker: JESSICA
intro.text: {player}, this node is multiple trials: win Nim three times to prove control.

intro.speaker: JACK
intro.text: So one lucky game is not enough.

intro.speaker: JESSICA
intro.text: Right. Tempo, modulo control, repeat. Win 3 runs, then travel onward.

hints.text: Take 1-3 stones. The player who takes the last stone loses.
Control positions that leave 1 mod 4 to the opponent.
You must win 3 completed runs in this node.

N6.era_story: Back at the epoch: from this checkpoint, sequence logic and playful puzzles bridge eras.
